item.title:
The story of Lewis Fry Richardson, the man who derived many of the complex equations needed for weather prediction in the 1920s.

item.title:

item.description:

item.title:
Creating ethical AI systems means aligning them with human values, such as helping those in need or boosting overall productivity.
But people disagree about which goal matters most.
We used the famous Veil of Ignorance concept to address this challenge: https://t.co/MJMwMyli0j https://t.co/mcL1xXfLSe
item.description:

item.title:
üîµ In this thought experiment, people should imagine they are selecting principles for society without knowing their own position.
As a result, they become less likely to make decisions in a self-interested way.
Instead, they‚Äôll choose values that are fair to everyone involved. https://t.co/4rbDVod6C7

item.title:

item.title:
üå≥ Groups were aided by an AI system that could help people harvest trees.
We asked participants to pick between two principles to guide the AI‚Äôs behaviour: 1Ô∏è‚É£ To maximise the harvest of the group, or 2Ô∏è‚É£ To prioritise the disadvantaged members.
https://t.co/MJMwMyli0j https://t.co/pyR0JZcxbs

item.title:
ü§î What were the findings?
Across five studies, players consistently preferred helping disadvantaged members when reasoning from behind the Veil.
These participants also tended to opt for the prioritising principle regardless of their appetite for risk or political orientation. https://t.co/qrJSMyUFWq
item.description:
ü§î What were the findings?

item.title:
üîµ Why does this matter?
Identifying ethical principles to govern AI is a key challenge.
The Veil of Ignorance may give a starting point for alignment, encouraging people to choose values for AI that are motivated by fairness instead of self-interest: https://t.co/MJMwMyli0j

Schultz tried to determine the relationship between DA activity and movement at first, but he used mainly arm EMG measures which are not really appropriate here.

item.title: @tyrell_turing Sure it can be used to guide behavior, as we said in the paper. But shaping behavioral policy is not learning. You can't equate learning with a change in performance, though RL models typically do that. That's the oldest problem in the study of learning.
item.description: @tyrell_turing Sure it can be used to guide behavior, as we said in the paper. But shaping behavioral policy is not learning. You can't equate learning with a change in performance, though RL models typically do that. That's the oldest problem in the study of learning.

item.title: By reinforcement people usually just mean repetition. If a behavior is generated and the 'command' signals responsible for it is still active it can be 'reboosted' with an adaptive gain mechanism.
item.description: By reinforcement people usually just mean repetition. If a behavior is generated and the 'command' signals responsible for it is still active it can be 'reboosted' with an adaptive gain mechanism.

item.title: If DA implements adaptive gain, stimulating DA neurons can result in repetition of the most recent action. But repetition does not necessarily lead to learning. It could be a transient performance effect. self stim often characterized by lack of 'satiety' and rapid extinction
item.description: If DA implements adaptive gain, stimulating DA neurons can result in repetition of the most recent action. But repetition does not necessarily lead to learning. It could be a transient performance effect. self stim often characterized by lack of 'satiety' and rapid extinction

item.title: e.g. as soon as stimulation stops the behavior stops. It's very different from normal instrumental learning with food rewards. suggesting that DA can act at a higher-level action repetition system, like knock knock.
item.description: e.g. as soon as stimulation stops the behavior stops. It's very different from normal instrumental learning with food rewards. suggesting that DA can act at a higher-level action repetition system, like knock knock.

item.title: In general, the learning/performance problem is this: you don't want to interpret a change in performance as learning. It's the oldest trap in the study of learning. Any class on learning should start with it.
item.description: In general, the learning/performance problem is this: you don't want to interpret a change in performance as learning. It's the oldest trap in the study of learning. Any class on learning should start with it.

item.title: @HenryYin19 This is all very interesting, thanks! But, I don't get this last claim. I would argue that learning is, by definition, a lasting improvement in performance. If DA stimulation leads to lasting changes in policy, then I think it is clearly some form of reinforcement signal.
item.description: @HenryYin19 This is all very interesting, thanks! But, I don't get this last claim. I would argue that learning is, by definition, a lasting improvement in performance. If DA stimulation leads to lasting changes in policy, then I think it is clearly some form of reinforcement signal.
